unnormalised: So, I did it again. Fell victim to the siren song of online shopping. You know the one – that little notification that whispers sweet nothings like "70% off!" or "Limited time offer!" before promptly draining your bank account. This time, it was on "Glamazon.in" – don't judge, they have good deals (sometimes). I ended up buying 3 sarees (even though I only wear them, like, twice a year), a gadget I definitely don’t need, and a lifetime supply of chai. The final bill came to ₹8750, which, let’s be honest, is roughly the same as my rent for the month (I wish!).

unnormalised: It all started innocently enough. I was just browsing, as one does on a boring Tuesday afternoon. Saw an ad for "Ethnic Emporium" with a saree that screamed "Diwali!" – even though Diwali is, like, 6 months away. Next thing I know, I'm adding it to my cart. Then, "Oh look! A matching blouse for only ₹499!" And then another saree because, well, why not? They were offering "Buy 2 Get 1 Free" - a trap I ALWAYS fall into. I mean, who can resist a "free" saree, even if you didn't need the first two?!

unnormalised: And then came the tech section. I spotted a "Smart Dustbin" - yes, a dustbin with its own microchip (the future is now!). Marked down from ₹3999 to ₹1999. I reasoned that it would "revolutionize my waste management system" (spoiler alert: it hasn't). But the price was too tempting, and 1 click later, the damage was done. My credit card company probably thinks I'm having a mid-life crisis.

unnormalised: Of course, no online shopping spree is complete without a detour to the grocery section. I needed chai. Obviously. "Masala Chai Delight" was on sale - 500 grams for ₹250. Figured it would get me through at least a week (I’m an optimist). Added 2 packets to my cart. Realized I was out of biscuits. Added 3 packets of Britannia Good Day cookies for ₹60 each. What can I say? A girl’s gotta have her biscuits.

unnormalised: The checkout process is always a comedy of errors. I fumble with OTPs (One-Time Passwords), trying to remember my mother’s maiden name for the security question, and praying that my internet connection doesn't give up on me mid-transaction. After what feels like an eternity, the payment finally goes through. I get a confirmation email stating my order will arrive between 27/07/2024 and 31/07/2024. That's a pretty big window, but hey, who's counting?

unnormalised: Now, the waiting game begins. I spend the next few days obsessively tracking my order, checking for updates every 5 minutes. I get increasingly anxious about whether the delivery guy will find my house, or if the sarees will actually look as good in person as they did in the pictures. The suspense is almost unbearable. I also hope I remembered to use that discount code I found!

unnormalised: Moral of the story? Online shopping is a dangerous game. It's fun, it's convenient, but it's also a black hole for your hard-earned rupees. But hey, at least I'll have a stylish saree and a smart dustbin to cry into when my next credit card bill arrives. Maybe I should put myself on an online shopping ban... or maybe just buy one more saree? Decisions, decisions...
